message_1: Suppose we have a unit sphere in $\mathbb{R}^3$, and we want to find the maximum number of nonintersecting great circles that can be drawn on it such that each point on the sphere belongs to at least one of the great circles. What is this maximum number?
message_2:
To maximize the number of nonintersecting great circles on a unit sphere such that each point belongs to at least one of the great circles, we can consider the arrangement of these great circles as a polyhedron inscribed in the sphere. In this case, the great circles are the edges of the polyhedron.

The most symmetrical polyhedron that can be inscribed in a sphere is the regular icosahedron, which has 12 vertices, 30 edges, and 20 faces. Each edge of the icosahedron corresponds to a great circle on the sphere.

Therefore, the maximum number of nonintersecting great circles that can be drawn on a unit sphere such that each point belongs to at least one of the great circles is 30.
